thread.title: Takeaways: ISU faces tough trio of opponents
thread.title_full: Takeaways: ISU faces tough trio of opponents

author: desmoinesregister.com
title: Takeaways: ISU faces tough trio of opponents
text:
Opponents like Texas Tech are why coach Paul Rhoads say the Cyclones switched defenses. Randy Peterson
Buy Photo Iowa State head coach Paul Rhoads runs out on to the field to shake the hand of Kansas head coach David Beaty after their game at Jack Trice Stadium in Ames on Saturday, October 3, 2015. (Photo: Brian Powers/The Register) Buy Photo
31 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN 2 COMMENT EMAIL MORE AMES, Ia. — Baylor, TCU and Texas Tech are the highest scoring teams in the Big 12 Conference. They’re the top three in total offense and passing offense.
They’re also the next three opponents on Iowa State’s schedule:
At Texas Tech Saturday, at home against TCU, and then at Baylor.
That’s second-ranked TCU and third-ranked Baylor, by the way.
DES MOINES REGISTER
Peterson: Cyclones entering the world of 'made-for-TV football'
“You’re talking about outstanding football programs,” Cyclones coach Paul Rhoads said during Monday's weekly session with reporters. “You’re talking about a Texas Tech football team that started extremely fast, then ran into the second and third-ranked team in the country.
“We’re on the verge of doing that ourselves; they just beat us to it.”
Adding to the sack total
That probably won’t happen, but it won’t be the fault of an Iowa State defense with 14 sacks, the second most in the Big 12.
Texas Tech quarterback Patrick Mahomes gets rid of the ball so quickly that he has been sacked just once in five games.
“Opponents have only got there once, because he gets the ball out of his hands fast,” Rhoads said. “To only be sacked one time tells you about what kind of player he is, and what kind of offense thy run.”
That doesn’t mean the Cyclones won’t even try, however.
“We have to let him know we’re there — at least cause his feet to shuffle a bit and maybe cause him to hold onto the ball a little longer.”
Buy Photo Iowa State's Sam Richardson tries to avoid the tackle of Kansas defensive end Dorance Armstrong, Jr. during their game at Jack Trice Stadium in Ames on Saturday, October 3, 2015. (Photo: Brian Powers/The Register)
More Richardson wins?
Quarterback Sam Richardson finally broke through as a winner while starting a Big 12 game, Saturday’s 38-13 handling of Kansas ending his 14-game conference starting drought.
How might that translate to the future?
“We’re very pleased with how Sam’s running our offense, and what he’s given us,” Rhoads said. “The win will give him added confidence. He’ll play a little lighter from here on out as far as being able to move around, because of the burden that’s been lifted off his shoulders.”
Mahomes will play
Texas Tech’s quarterback completed 32 of 50 passes for 415 yards in last Saturday’s 63-35 loss against third-ranked Baylor, and he did it despite a sore knee.
“He's getting treatment every day, and he told me it feels a lot better, so hopefully by this week he can be 100 percent,” coach Kliff Kingsbury told reporters Monday.
Kingsbury said Mahomes will start on Saturday, which isn’t exactly a surprise to Rhoads.
“He’s got great poise and great composure,” Rhoads said. “Coach Kingsbury does an excellent job with quarterbacks.”
He leads the Big 12 with an average of 367.2 passing yards a game. He has thrown 14 touchdowns passes against just five interceptions.
DES MOINES REGISTER
ISU holder's celebrations steal the limelight
Defending Tech starts with ISU’s offense
There’s a fine line between ball control and scoring, Rhoads said.
“We don’t want to compromise flow just to accomplish one goal,” he said when asked about the importance of keeping the Red Raiders’ offense sidelined.
“The goal is to score points on offense, and in the process of doing that, score more than your opponent.”
The burgeoning freshman running back opens up a lot of opportunities for Iowa State's offense Randy Peterson
Warren right, Warren left, Warren up the middle
Texas Tech is the most prolific passing team in college football. The Red Raiders’ Patrick Mahomes is one of the nation’s top quarterbacks.
So how does 2-2 Iowa State expect to win Saturday’s 2:30 p.m. game in Lubbock?
Rush the football.
Tailback Mike Warren and the offensive line will be running against a defense that’s allowing 277.4 yards a game, the worst in the Big 12.
“We have to continue to work to run the football,” coach Paul Rhoads said at his weekly press conference Monday. “How much Mike’s a part of that could change by game (or) it could change during the course of a game.
“Mike’s going to be very active.”
DES MOINES REGISTER
Iowa State's Warren: 'They're probably going to be coming for me'
Cyclone sports columnist Randy Peterson has been reporting on ISU during the past five decades. Follow @RandyPete.
